title: Sport in South Australia
text:
Sport plays an important role in the business, community, social and cultural life in <a href="South%20Australia">South Australia</a>.
Sport as entertainment plays an important role with South Australia having the second highest rate of event attendance of all states and territories with 49% of South Australians aged 15 years and over attending a sporting event each year.
Regional and rural opportunities to participate in sport plays an important role in community life throughout SA. SA has developed a range of programs in supporting inclusive sports pathways focusing on specific populations groups such as indigenous, mature-aged, early childhood, people with disabilities and women.
Significant elite sporting events in South Australia include the <a href="Tour%20Down%20Under">Tour Down Under</a>, <a href="Clipsal%20500">Clipsal 500</a>, <a href="Adelaide%20Cup">Adelaide Cup</a>, International Cricket series and hosting various <a href="Australian%20Swimming%20Championships">Australian Swimming Championships</a>. Major events have been shown to bring significant economic benefit to the state.
South Australian-based teams are represented in almost all <a href="Australia">Australia</a>n major professional sporting codes including the <a href="Adelaide%20Football%20Club">Adelaide Football Club</a> and <a href="Port%20Adelaide%20Football%20Club">Port Adelaide Football Club</a> in the <a href="Australian%20Football%20League">Australian Football League</a>, the <a href="South%20Australia%20cricket%20team">Redbacks</a> and <a href="South%20Australian%20Scorpions">Scorpions</a> in cricket, <a href="Adelaide%20United">Adelaide United</a> in the <a href="A-League">A-League</a> and <a href="W-League%20%28Australia%29">W-League</a>, <a href="Adelaide%2036ers">Adelaide 36ers</a> in the <a href="National%20Basketball%20League%20%28Australasia%29">National Basketball League</a>, <a href="Adelaide%20Lightning">Adelaide Lightning</a> in the <a href="Women%27s%20National%20Basketball%20League">Women's National Basketball League</a>, and the <a href="Adelaide%20Thunderbirds">Adelaide Thunderbirds</a> in the <a href="ANZ%20Championship">ANZ Championship</a> for netball.
The most popular spectator sports in South Australia by attendance are Australian Rules football (31%), motor sports (14%), horse racing (8%), cricket (5%) and soccer (4%).
South Australia boasts world-class venues for high performance sport including the <a href="Adelaide%20Oval">Adelaide Oval</a>, <a href="Adelaide%20Super-Drome">Adelaide Super-Drome</a>, <a href="Netball%20SA%20Stadium">Netball SA Stadium</a>, and <a href="Hindmarsh%20Stadium">Hindmarsh Stadium</a>.
All major sporting codes within South Australia field representative teams on the national stage. South Australia's official sporting colours are red, blue and gold.
Participation.
Research shows two thirds of South Australians are involved in sport or recreation with around forty percent of those involved, participating in organised sporting activities. Significantly people from regional areas are more likely to participate through a club based structure and are more likely to volunteer and to be a spectator than those in the Adelaide metropolitan area. It is estimated regional communities have an estimated one third of adults participating in exercise recreation and sport via a club or association and almost a quarter are involved as a coach, official, umpire or administrator.
Participation rates for males and females are similar and while overall, participation rates decline with age it was more so with males, while women's participation rates remain constant until they are over the age of 65.
Research shows walking, running, swimming, aerobics/fitness, golf, lawn bowls, weight training and cycling to be the most popular sports with strong participation by both men and women in South Australia. Historically not all sports have been available to women but that has changed with equal opportunity laws targeting discrimination based on gender.
Differences in participation rates by men and women relate to the football codes and netball, which have in the past been limited by opportunities for participation by genders not traditionally associated with the sport.
High performance sport.
South Australia has produced successful <a href="Olympic%20Games">Olympians</a>, <a href="Paralympian">Paralympian</a>s, <a href="Commonwealth%20Games">Commonwealth Games</a> representatives, world champions and national champions across a wide range of individual and team sports. The state has produced successful professional golfers including <a href="Jane%20Crafter">Jane Crafter</a> and Tamie Durdin, world-class tennis players including <a href="Lleyton%20Hewitt">Lleyton Hewitt</a>, <a href="John%20Fitzgerald%20%28tennis%29">John Fitzgerald</a>, <a href="Mark%20Woodforde">Mark Woodforde</a>, <a href="Darren%20Cahill">Darren Cahill</a>, <a href="Roger%20Rasheed">Roger Rasheed</a> and <a href="Alicia%20Molik">Alicia Molik</a>, and many other successful world champions including squash player <a href="Vicki%20Cardwell">Vicki Cardwell</a> and <a href="Kylie%20Halliday">Kylie Halliday</a> in <a href="sport%20aerobics">sport aerobics</a>.
The establishment of the South Australian Sports Institute in 1982 played a role in supporting elite individuals and team sports. Currently it has high performance programs for rowing, Paralympic, netball, canoe sprint, swimming, cycling, trampoline, diving, volleyball, hockey and water polo and conducts talent search activities throughout the state. A new building for the Institute is being constructed at <a href="Mile%20End%2C%20South%20Australia">Mile End, South Australia</a>, with funding from the <a href="Government%20of%20South%20Australia">Government of South Australia</a>.
Team sports.
Australian rules football.
Australian rules football is the most popular spectator sport in South Australia with an attendance level (of at least one match per year) of 31% of the population, compared with a national average of 16%.
Two South Australian teams participate in the <a href="Australian%20Football%20League">Australian Football League</a>; the <a href="Adelaide%20Football%20Club">Adelaide Football Club</a>, known as the Crows, and the <a href="Port%20Adelaide%20Football%20Club">Port Adelaide Football Club</a>, nicknamed the Power. Adelaide also has a women's team in the <a href="AFL%20Women%27s">AFL Women's</a> league. South Australia also has a domestic men's and women's competition which is strongly supported, the <a href="South%20Australian%20National%20Football%20League">South Australian National Football League</a>.
In 1990 a group of women established the <a href="South%20Australian%20Women%27s%20Football%20League">South Australian Women's Football League</a> after an exhibition match against Victoria. The league has seen seven of its state representatives making the All-Australian team which is selected from participants at the <a href="AFL%20Women%27s%20National%20Championships">AFL Women's National Championships</a>.
In May 2013, the Australian Football League created a 'draft' for women to form two teams from the top 50 women Australian rules footballers in the nation to participate in an exhibition game before the Round 14 Melbourne versus Bulldogs AFL teams. Many South Australian women chose to nominate. <a href="Melbourne%20Demons">Melbourne Demons</a> drafted Alexandra Price from Port Adelaide FC and Bronwyn Davey from Greenacres FC while <a href="Western%20Bulldogs">Western Bulldogs</a> drafted <a href="Courtney%20Cramey">Courtney Cramey</a>, Morphetville Park.
Netball.
Netball is a significant sport in South Australia with a wide range of participation opportunities across metropolitan, regional and rural locations within the state.
The <a href="Adelaide%20Thunderbirds">Adelaide Thunderbirds</a> have participated in the premier netball league in Australasia, winning premierships in 1998, 1999 in the CBT, and 2010 in the ANZ Championship. Many South Australian players have represented Australia, including World Championship player and Australian captain <a href="Natalie%20von%20Bertouch">Natalie von Bertouch</a>, <a href="Rebecca%20Sanders">Rebecca Sanders</a> and <a href="Kathryn%20Harby-Williams">Kathryn Harby-Williams</a>.
South Australia also participates in the <a href="Australian%20Netball%20League">Australian Netball League</a>. In 2012 <a href="Southern%20Force%20%28netball%29">Southern Force</a> took the title.
Netball continues to have a strong metro, regional and intrastate competition throughout South Australia with around 70,000 women and men participating across the state.
Cricket.
Cricket is a popular sport in South Australia and attracts big crowds in the men's game at the top level. It is popular with both boys and girls at community level and there are high performance pathways available for men and women. South Australia's representative cricket teams, the <a href="South%20Australia%20cricket%20team">Redbacks</a> for men and the SA Scorpions for women participate in national competitions.
SA has produced outstanding Australian cricketers in both the men's and women's games including <a href="Vic%20Richardson">Victor Richardson</a>, <a href="Terry%20Jenner">Terry Jenner</a>, <a href="Ian%20Chappell">Ian Chappell</a>, <a href="Greg%20Chappell">Greg Chappell</a>, <a href="David%20Hookes">David Hookes</a>, <a href="Jason%20Gillespie">Jason Gillespie</a>, <a href="Shaun%20Tait">Shaun Tait</a>, <a href="Lyn%20Fullston">Lyn Fullston</a>, <a href="Jill%20Kennare">Jill Kennare</a> and <a href="Karen%20Rolton">Karen Rolton</a>. <a href="Karen%20Rolton">Karen Rolton</a>, a left-handed batsman and occasional left-arm medium-paced bowler, has scored the most runs for Australia in <a href="women%27s%20Test%20cricket">women's Test cricket</a> and SA Scorpion's player <a href="Lauren%20Ebsary">Lauren Ebsary</a> was part of the successful 2013 Australian <a href="2013%20Women%27s%20Cricket%20World%20Cup">Women's World Cup</a> victory.
South Australia's men have had thirteen <a href="Sheffield%20Shield">Sheffield Shield</a> victories with their last Shield success coming in 1995-96.
South Australia's women have won five national championships with wins in 1951/52, 1979/80 and an outstanding era of wins in 1992/93, 1993/94, and 1994/95.
Soccer.
South Australia's sole representative in the national <a href="A-League">A-League</a> competition is <a href="Adelaide%20United%20FC">Adelaide United FC</a>. They won the <a href="2016%20A-League%20Grand%20Final">2016 A-League Grand Final</a> and have won two <a href="pre-season%20cups">pre-season cups</a> and have made the finals every year except for 2009 and 2012 since the <a href="A-league">A-league</a> started in 2005. Adelaide United have been one of the most successful teams in the <a href="A-league">A-league</a>, despite failing to win an A-league Grand Final in their first two attempts. They have qualified for the <a href="AFC%20Champions%20League">AFC Champions League</a> 4 times, making them the most represented club in Australia. Of these appearances they made the round of 16 in 2010, were runners up in 2008, and have made the round of 16 in the ongoing <a href="2012%20AFC%20Champions%20League">2012 AFC Champions League</a>. Their home ground is <a href="Hindmarsh%20Stadium">Hindmarsh Stadium</a>, which has a capacity of 16,500. Hindmarsh was one of four non-<a href="Sydney">Sydney</a> venues chosen to host matches as part of the <a href="Football%20at%20the%202000%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20tournament">Men's Football tournament</a> during the <a href="2000%20Summer%20Olympic%20Games">2000 Summer Olympic Games</a>.
<a href="Adelaide%20City%20FC">Adelaide City</a> remains South Australia's most successful club, having won three <a href="National%20Soccer%20League">National Soccer League</a> titles and three <a href="NSL%20Cup">NSL Cup</a>s. City was the first side from South Australia to ever win a continental title when it won the <a href="1987%20Oceania%20Club%20Championship">1987 Oceania Club Championship</a> and it has also won a record 17 <a href="National%20Premier%20Leagues%20South%20Australia">South Australian championships</a> and 17 <a href="FFSA%20Federation%20Cup">Federation Cups</a>. Adelaide City contests the <a href="Adelaide%20derby">Adelaide derby</a> against its crosstown rival <a href="West%20Adelaide%20SC">West Adelaide</a>, also a former national champion having been the first South Australian club to win the national league in <a href="1978%20National%20Soccer%20League">1978</a>.
SASi Pirates were National Champions in 1997 and 98 in the <a href="Women%27s%20National%20Soccer%20League">Women's National Soccer League</a>. Adelaide United 'Lady Reds' compete in the current national competition, the <a href="W-League%20%28Australia%29">W-League</a>. The state has produced Australian representatives such as <a href="Sharon%20Black">Sharon Black</a> and <a href="Dianne%20Alagich">Dianne Alagich</a> who have contributed to the international success of the <a href="Australia%20women%27s%20national%20soccer%20team">Matlidas</a>.
Baseball.
South Australia is home to <a href="Baseball%20SA">Baseball SA</a>, which has a 12 club division 1 competition in the Adelaide metropolitan area.
Adelaide was also home to the former <a href="Adelaide%20Giants">Adelaide Giants</a> in the defunct <a href="Australian%20Baseball%20League%20%281989-1999%29">Australian Baseball League</a>. A new baseball league was approved by the SA sports commission and started in November 2010. Adelaide's team is called the <a href="Adelaide%20Bite">Adelaide Bite</a>. They formerly played their home games at <a href="Norwood%20Oval">Norwood Oval</a>, but moved to the <a href="Diamond%20Sports%20Stadium">Diamond Sports Stadium</a> in 2016 due to renovations at Norwood.
Basketball.
South Australia has a long history of producing outstanding representatives which have shaped and influenced Australia's high international standing in both men's and women's basketball. High profile players and coaches include Olympians <a href="Lindsay%20Gaze">Lindsay Gaze</a>, <a href="Phil%20Smyth">Phil Smyth</a>, Peter Ali, <a href="Darryl%20Pearce">Darryl Pearce</a>, <a href="Mark%20Bradtke">Mark Bradtke</a>, <a href="Mike%20McKay%20%28basketball%29">Mike McKay</a>, <a href="Tony%20Ronaldson">Tony Ronaldson</a>, <a href="Brett%20Wheeler">Brett Wheeler</a>, <a href="Paul%20Rogers%20%28basketball%29">Paul Rogers</a>, <a href="Brad%20Newley">Brad Newley</a> and <a href="Brett%20Maher%20%28basketball%29">Brett Maher</a>, as well as other <a href="Australian%20boomers">Australian Boomers</a> such as <a href="NBA">NBA</a> players including <a href="Luke%20Schenscher">Luke Schenscher</a> (also a 36ers player) and <a href="Joe%20Ingles">Joe Ingles</a> all came from (and in some cases still live in) Adelaide.
The Adelaide 36ers won <a href="National%20Basketball%20League%20%28Australasia%29">NBL</a> Championships in <a href="1986%20NBL%20season">1986</a>, <a href="1998%20NBL%20season">1998</a>, <a href="1998%E2%80%9399%20NBL%20season">1998–99</a> and <a href="2001%E2%80%9302%20NBL%20season">2001–02</a> and finished runner up in <a href="1985%20NBL%20season">1985</a>, <a href="1994%20NBL%20season">1994</a> and <a href="2013-14%20NBL%20season">2013-14</a>. The <a href="West%20Adelaide%20Bearcats">West Adelaide Bearcats</a> (who's NBL team merged with the 36ers in 1985) won the NBL Championship in <a href="1982%20NBL%20season">1982</a> and finished runner up in <a href="1983%20NBL%20season">1983</a>.
In women's basketball SA has produced outstanding Olympians including <a href="Rachael%20Sporn">Rachael Sporn</a>, <a href="Erin%20Phillips">Erin Phillips</a> and <a href="Laura%20Hodges">Laura Hodges</a>. SA teams have won numerous national championships, with the <a href="North%20Adelaide%20Rockets">North Adelaide Rockets</a> winning in <a href="1990%20WNBL%20season">1990</a> while finishing runner up in <a href="1981%20WIBC%20season">1981</a> (the inaugural season of the <a href="Women%27s%20National%20Basketball%20League">WNBL</a>) and <a href="1988%20WNBL%20season">1988</a>. The <a href="Adelaide%20Lightning">Adelaide Lightning</a> creating a historic era of success in <a href="1994%20WNBL%20season">1994</a>, <a href="1995%20WNBL%20season">1995</a>, <a href="1996%20WNBL%20season">1996</a> and <a href="1998%20WNBL%20season">1998</a> where it won 4 out of 5 National Championship Finals in the WNBL, as well as <a href="2007%E2%80%9308%20WNBL%20season">2007–08</a>. The Lightning also finished runner up in <a href="1997%20WNBL%20season">1997</a> and <a href="1999%E2%80%932000%20WNBL%20season">1999–2000</a>. The West Adelaide Bearcats finished as WNBL runner up in <a href="1984%20WNBL%20season">1984</a> while the Noarlunga Tigers finished runner up in <a href="1985%20WNBL%20season">1985</a>. Adelaide born <a href="Brendan%20Flynn">Brendan Flynn</a> was the coach of the <a href="Australian%20Opals">Australian Opals</a> at the <a href="Basketball%20at%20the%201984%20Summer%20Olympics">1984 Summer Olympics</a>.
Lacrosse.
South Australia has dominated the Women's Lacrosse National Championships having won 32 out of 51 National championships since competitions started in 1961. South Australia won regularly during the 60's and 70's but in 1985 begun its total domination when it won the first of 11 National Championships in a row.
SA Coach Peter Koshnitsky having established a women's lacrosse program with the South Australian Sports Institute helped forge this success in partnership with outstanding leader and Australian & State captain and World Champion, <a href="Jenny%20Williams%20%28sportsperson%29">Jenny Williams</a> and other players of this era. The legacy of this era was highlighted by the continued success by South Australian teams at national championship level with success in 1997 and a further run of wins with six in a row from 1999 until 2005.
South Australia has produced significant players during this period who have had incredible careers at international level contributing importantly to the 1986 and 2005 IFWLA World Championship victories. Many South Australian players have also had success in the United States' NCAA Women's Lacrosse Competition including <a href="Hannah%20Nielsen">Hannah Nielsen</a> and arguably the world's best player, Australian World Champion, <a href="Jen%20Adams">Jen Adams</a>.
In Men's Lacrosse South Australia has won 12 National Championships including three in a row from 2001 - 2003, and won again in 2012. In 2003 <a href="Peter%20Inge">Peter Inge</a> became the first Australian to play in <a href="Major%20League%20Lacrosse">Major League Lacrosse</a> in the USA.
<a href="http%3A//lacrossesa.com.au/">Lacrosse SA</a> is the peak body for lacrosse in South Australia, managing competitions for Women and Men, and Girls and Boys from age 8 to adults. While the primary focus revolves around the main field lacrosse season from April to September, differing formats of lacrosse including Box Lacrosse, Junior and Senior indoor competitions, modified preseason, University and High School competitions offer opportunities to enjoy lacrosse year round.
Hockey.
South Australia has produced many fine international representatives and successful Olympians as part of the powerhouse performances of Australian Hockey on the international stage. Kookaburras representatives include <a href="Robert%20Haigh">Robert Haigh</a>, <a href="Trevor%20Smith%20%28field%20hockey%29">Trevor Smith</a>, <a href="Paul%20Lewis%20%28field%20hockey%29">Paul Lewis</a> and <a href="Craig%20Victory">Craig Victory</a>.
South Australian women have featured prominently in the Hockeyroos. In fact in 1914 in the very first Australian women’s test vs England, SA had five players in the Australian team as well as coach Judy Smith. In the 1980s and 1990s, South Australia saw many fine players achieving Olympic success including <a href="Sandra%20Pisani">Sandra Pisani</a>, <a href="Juliet%20Haslam">Juliet Haslam</a> and <a href="Alison%20Peek">Alison Peek</a>. State representative team SASI Suns won the National Championship in 1995 and the Southern Suns won in 2011 competing in the Australian Hockey League.
Softball.
South Australia last won the national championship in 1956 but has produced representatives at international and Olympic level including <a href="Tracey%20Moseley">Tracey Moseley</a> and <a href="Simmone%20Morrow">Simmone Morrow</a>.
Rugby league.
The state <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> federation is the <a href="South%20Australian%20Rugby%20League">South Australian Rugby League</a>. The game traces its roots in the state back to the 1940s, when the Port Adelaide <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> team split in four, and defected to <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a>.
South Australia's only professional rugby league team, the <a href="Adelaide%20Rams">Adelaide Rams</a>, had a short but eventful existence. Originally the <a href="Australian%20Rugby%20League">Australian Rugby League</a> planned to relocate a Sydney team to Adelaide but the <a href="Super%20League%20war">Super League war</a> and the <a href="South%20Australian%20Rugby%20League">SARL</a>'s decision to align themselves with the News Ltd <a href="Super%20League%20%28Australia%29">Super League</a> in 1995 shut that idea down. Later in 1995, with Super League still only consisting of nine teams and Melbourne still aligned with the <a href="Australian%20Rugby%20League">ARL</a>, a decision was made to give Adelaide the 10th Super League license.
Brought into existence for the <a href="Super%20League%20%28Australia%29%20season%201997">1997</a> <a href="Super%20League%20%28Australia%29">Super League</a> season, the team had instant success. In <a href="National%20Rugby%20League%20season%201998">1998</a> they were selected to join the 20-team <a href="National%20Rugby%20League">National Rugby League</a>; however, rumours abounded that they were to be axed from the 1999 season as part of a rationalisation of teams (from 20 to 14) in the competition. At present however, the <a href="South%20Australian%20Rugby%20League">South Australian Rugby League</a> still operates a local semi-professional competition consisting of both junior and adult teams from across Adelaide.
Rugby union.
<a href="South%20Australian%20Rugby%20Union">South Australian Rugby Union</a> or "SA Rugby" is the governing body in the state.
Adelaide also hosts a <a href="rugby%20sevens">rugby sevens</a> tournament. The tournament consists of multiple national teams of seven players that represent their country.
American football.
Gridiron is played in the <a href="South%20Australian%20Gridiron%20Association">South Australian Gridiron Association</a>. Current teams are the <a href="Southern%20District%20Oilers">Southern District Oilers</a>, South City Chiefs, Eastside Razorbacks, <a href="Port%20Adelaide%20Spartans">Port Adelaide Spartans</a> and the Adelaide Eagles.
South Australia also fields a state team known as the SA Swarm.
